author: Michel Roux Jr.
method: For the caramelised onions, heat the oil and butter in a pan and add the onions, salt and pepper. Cook over a low heat for 20-30 minutes, stirring from time to time, until golden-brown, soft and sticky.  For the hotdogs, chop both fats then place in a food processor with the mince and all the other remaining ingredients, except the casings. Blend to a smooth paste. Fill a large piping bag with the hotdog mix and carefully fill the sheep casing. Twist the filled casings to separate into individual hotdogs, around 15cm/6in long. Tie off the ends to seal in the mixture.  Place in a pan of cold water and bring up to 86C/187F. The water must not exceed this temperature. Poach gently (so as not to break the casings) for about 10 minutes, or until the pork has cooked through. Drain well and serve in a brioche roll with mustard.
ingredients: 1 tbsp olive oil,  25g/1oz unsalted butter,  2 large onions, peeled and sliced,  ½ tsp salt,  ½ tsp pepper,  160g/5¾oz cured pork fat (lardo or salo, available from specialist online suppliers),  25g/1oz pork back fat (available from a butcher),  250g/9oz lean pork mince,  2 free-range egg whites,  1 tsp cornflour,  salt and freshly ground black pepper,  freshly grated nutmeg,  pinch ground coriander,  4 tbsp frozen milk,  natural sheep casings, cleaned thoroughly under cold running water (available from specialist online suppliers),  brioche rolls,  mustard
